questions.text: A 45 y/o male patient is admitted to the ICU following a major road traffic accident, resulting in multiple fractures and abdominal injuries. The patient is currently unable to take oral nutrition. He is expected to require enteral feeding for more than 3 weeks. Imaging studies reveal delayed gastric emptying and significant gastric distension. What is the most appropriate route for enteral nutrition in this patient?

A 38-year-old male involved in a motor vehicle accident has been in the ICU for several days with multiple injuries including head and abdominal trauma. The ICU team is considering starting enteral feeding. Which of the following findings would most likely contraindicate the initiation of enteral nutrition in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Indications

Contraindications

Protein-energy malnutrition with inadequate oral intake

Small bowel obstruction or ileus

Dysphagia except for liquids

Severe diarrhea

Major trauma or surgery when returning to dietary intake is prolonged

Proximal small intestinal fistula (Option C)

Inflammatory bowel disease (Option A ruled out)

Severe Pancreatitis

(the food particles stimulate the release of pancreatic enzymes, ultimately worsening the symptoms.)

Distal low-output enterocutaneous fistula (Option B ruled out)

GI bleed

Category

Complications

Tube-Related Complications
  • Malposition
  • Displacement
  • Blockage
  • Leakage
  • Erosion of skin and mucosa

Gastrointestinal Complications (due to high osmotic load)
  • Diarrhea
  • Abdominal cramps
  • Aspiration
  • Constipation (Option D ruled out)

Metabolic Complications
  • Dyselectrolytemia (increased risk)
  • Deficiency of vitamins, minerals, and trace elements

Infective Complications
  • Endogenous
  • Exogenous

questions.text: A 45-year-old male recovering from gastrointestinal surgery is on total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Initially, he was receiving a 2-in-1 TPN formulation. Due to ongoing nutritional needs, the medical team switches him to a 3-in-1 TPN formulation. Which component is newly included in the 3-in-1 formulation that was not in the 2-in-1?
questions.explanation:
3 in 1 formulation

2 in 1 formulation

Solutions with lipids (Option C)

Solutions without lipids

60/20/20

  • 60% by dextrose
  • 20% by amino acids
  • 20% by fat.

75/25

  • 75% by dextrose (OPTION B ruled out)
  • 25% by amino acids (OPTION A ruled out)
  • No lipids used (OPTION C)

Fiber is absent in both the formulations (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with severe pancreatitis is initiated on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to his inability to tolerate enteral feeding. Shortly after the central venous catheter is inserted, he complains of sudden onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. On examination, his breath sounds are decreased on the same side of the catheter insertion. What is the most likely complication that has occurred?
questions.explanation:
Line Insertion Complications
  • Pneumothorax (most dangerous)
  • Misplacement of catheter

Line-Related Complications
  • Sepsis (most common)
  • Thrombosis (more common with long-term catheter use)
  • Electrolyte imbalances (e.g., refeeding syndrome)

Metabolic Complications
  • Blood sugar derangements (hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia)
  • Liver dysfunction
  • Metabolic bone disease
  • Vitamin deficiencies

questions.text: A 45 year old male severely malnourished patient with a history of chronic alcoholism and recent weight loss is admitted in the hospital. After stabilization, he is started on a high-calorie enteral feeding regimen to address his nutritional deficiencies. Within 48 hours of initiating feeding, he begins to have muscle weakness, difficulty in breathing and is confused. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities in the blood is least likely to be associated with his current condition?
questions.explanation:
One or more of the following: (OR)

Two or more of the following:

BMI <16 kg/m2

BMI <18.5 kg/m2

Unintentional weight loss >15% within the last 3-6 months

Unintentional weight loss >10% within the last 3-6 months.

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 10 days

Little or no nutritional intake for more than 5 days.

Low potassium, phosphate or magnesium levels prior to feeding

History of alcohol abuse or on medication, including insulin, chemotherapy, antacids or diuretics.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male undergoes abdominal surgery, and the surgeon plans to use a non-absorbable monofilament suture for skin closure to minimize tissue reaction and ensure long-term wound support. Which of the following sutures should be selected?
questions.explanation:
Monofilament

Polyfilament

Single strand of fiber

Multiple strands braided together

Smooth & strong

Easier to handle

Decreased chance of bacterial infection

Increased risk of infection due to the lodging of bacteria in crevices

Knots tied may become loose (6-8 knots)

Knots are stable (3-4 knots)

E.g.:

  • Prolene
  • Ethilon
  • Nylon

E.g.:

  • Silk
  • Linen
  • Polyglycolic acid (Dexon)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoes an open appendectomy, and plain catgut sutures are used for closing the muscle layer. Which of the following statements regarding these sutures is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Non-absorbable and provide long-term tensile strength

options.label: B
options.text: Made from synthetic materials and are highly resistant to enzymatic degradation

options.label: C
options.text: Primarily absorbed by enzymatic proteolysis and has variable tensile strength

options.label: D
options.text: Causes minimal tissue reaction and are preferred for patients with suture allergies

questions.correct_answer: C. Primarily absorbed by enzymatic proteolysis and has variable tensile strength
questions.explanation:
Suture

Plain Catgut

Chromic catgut

Frequent uses
  • Superficial vessels ligation
  • Subcutaneous tissues suturing Stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly

Same as catgut

Contraindications

Tissues that heal slowly and require prolonged support.

Same as catgut

Tissue reaction

High (OPTION D ruled out)

Moderate

Absorption rate

Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 7–10 days. (OPTION C) (Option A ruled out)

Phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation within 90 days.

Tensile strength retention in vivo
  • Lost within 7–10 days
  • Marked patient variability and unpredictable (Option C) (Option A ruled out)
  • Lost within 21–28 days
  • Marked patient variability and unpredictable

Raw material

Collagen derived from the submucosa of sheep small intestine. (OPTION B ruled out)

Collagen derived from the submucosa of sheep is tanned with chromium salts to improve handling and resist degradation in tissue.

Brown in colour

questions.text: A 30-year-old female undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, during which the surgeon uses Vicryl sutures to close the internal fascial layers. Postoperatively, the patient expresses concern about how long the sutures will remain in her body before being fully absorbed. What is the expected time frame for complete absorption of the Vicryl sutures in this case?

A 28-year-old male undergoes repair of a laceration on his forearm following a minor accident. The surgeon chooses monocryl for the subcutaneous layer and polyglycolic acid sutures for the deep dermal layer. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding these sutures in this case? Polyglycaparone is preferred over monocryl for subcuticular suturing Monocryl is a polymer of glycolide and caprolactone Polyglycolic acid exhibits highest affinity for adherence to E.coli and staph. aureus Patient is informed that monocryl will be completely absorbed in 180 days

A 45-year-old female undergoes an abdominal hysterectomy. The surgeon chooses to close the rectus sheath using PDS (polydioxanone) sutures due to their prolonged tensile strength. What is the expected time frame for the complete absorption of the polydioxanone sutures in this patient?

A 60-year-old woman with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with critical limb ischemia. She is scheduled for a femoral-popliteal bypass surgery to restore blood flow to her lower extremity. Which suture is preferred for vascular anastomosis?
Which of the following best describes Jenkins's rule in the context of abdominal wound closure?

options.label: A
options.text: Use of interrupted sutures with bites 2 cm apart to reduce wound tension.

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous suturing with bites 1 cm apart, avoiding suture locking to create a "spring coil" effect.

options.label: C
options.text: Continuous suturing with locking sutures, with bites placed 1 cm from the wound edge

options.label: D
options.text: Use of mattress sutures to maximize the tension across the wound during healing

questions.correct_answer: B. Continuous suturing with bites 1 cm apart, avoiding suture locking to create a "spring coil" effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended knot for securing the final stitch in a continuous suture technique during surgery?
questions.explanation:
Suture Technique

Description

Knot Used

Interrupted Sutures

Individual stitches, each tied off separately.

Tied like standard knots.

Continuous Sutures

Single length of suture for multiple stitches.

Aberdeen knot at the end. (Option B)

Mattress Sutures

Used to evert or invert wound edges. Tied like interrupted sutures.

Tied like standard knots.

Subcuticular Sutures

Placed under the epidermis for a cosmetic result, using absorbable sutures if needed.

Buried knot.

questions.text: Which of the following types of surgical needles is most appropriate for suturing tough or dense tissue such as skin and fascia?
questions.explanation:
Part

Shape/Type

Function/Usage

Body

Round-bodied

(Option A ruled out)

Separates tissue fibers, used in intestinal and cardiovascular surgery

Triangular

(Option B)

Cuts through tough or dense tissue like skin and fascia

Point

Round

Tapered end, general use

Conventional Cutting

Cutting edge inside curvature

Reversed Cutting

Cutting edge outside curvature

Blunt-ended

(Option C ruled out)

Minimizes needlestick injuries, used in abdominal wall closure

Shape

Half-circle

Gastrointestinal surgery

J-shaped

(Option D ruled out)

Laparoscopic port site closure

Quarter-circle

Eye surgery

Compound Curvature

Oral cavity procedures

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing technique used in the image given below.
questions.explanation:
Technique

Image

Description

Suture Placement

Interrupted Sutures

(Option A)

Needle inserted at 90-degree angle, passed through both sides of wound

Distance = tissue thickness, each suture twice as far from edge as previous

Continuous Sutures

(Option B ruled out)

Continuous placement after initial start, with suture appearing diagonal

Maintain proper tension, secure end with Aberdeen knot or final suture loop

Mattress Sutures

(Option C ruled out)

Vertical or horizontal, used to align wound edges

Passed through both sides, either vertically or horizontally

Subcuticular Sutures

(Option D ruled out)

Aesthetic closure with small bites of tissue, edges easily approximated

Absorbable or non-absorbable, secured with collar and bead or buried knot

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient is undergoing ileostomy closure and the surgeon opts for a hand-sewn anastomosis technique. Which of the following accurately describes the single-layer hand-sewn anastomosis technique?

options.label: A
options.text: It includes an inner continuous suture layer and an outer layer of interrupted sutures.

options.label: B
options.text: It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall, except the mucosa.

options.label: C
options.text: It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves placing a purse-string suture on the distal stump and stapling the anastomosis.

questions.correct_answer: B. It uses a continuous suture line through all layers of the bowel wall, except the mucosa.
questions.explanation:
Technique

Description

Material Used

Advantages and Risks

Single layer Anastomosis

Continuous suture line, all layers except mucosa (Option B) (Option A & C ruled out)

Monofilament absorbable

Or

Vicryl.

Quicker procedure

Potentially lower risk of leakage

Double Layer Anastomosis

Inner continuous layer (Albert layer) + outer interrupted sutures (Lembert layer)

Inner layer: Vicryl

Outer layer: Silk

Traditional method with additional support from the outer layer.

Risk: Potential for stricture formation.
